Genre: English mystery and miracle plays.
V. THE COWPERS. Man's disobedience and fall from Eden. Square brackets represent sections of text unclear or absent in the original and supplied by the current editor
[PERSONS OF THE PLAY. Dominus. Sathanas. Adam. Eua. Angelus.]

[Scene, Paradise.] Satanas incipit dicens, For woo my witte es in a were, That moffes me mykill in my mynde, The godhede Ã¾at I sawe so cleere, And parsayued Ã¾at he shuld take kynde, of a degree That he had wrought, and I denyed Ã¾at aungell kynde shuld it no?t be; And we were faire and bright, Ãerfore me thoght Ã¾at he The kynde of vs tane myght, And Ã¾er-at dedeyned me. 2. The kynde of man he thoght to take, And theratt hadde I grete envye, But he has made to hym a make, And harde to her I wol me hye, (that redy way) That purpose proue to putte it by, And fande to pike fro hym Ã¾at pray. My trauayle were wele sette Myght y hym so betraye, His likyng for to lette, And sone I schalle assaye. 3. In a worme liknes wille y wende, And founde to feyne a lowde lesynge. [Calls. Eue, Eue! Eua. Wha es Ã¾are? Satanas. I, a frende. And for thy gude es Ã¾e comynge, I hydir sought. Of all Ã¾e fruyt that ye se hynge In paradise, why eat ye noght? Eua. We may of tham ilkane Take al Ã¾at vs goode Ã¾ought, Save a tree outt is tane, Wolde do harm to neygh it ought. 4. Sat. And why Ã¾at tree? Ã¾at wolde I witte, Any more Ã¾an all othir by? Eua. For oure Lord god forbeedis vs itt, The frute Ã¾er of, Adam nor I to neghe it nere, And yf we dide we both shuld dye, He saide, and sese our solace sere. Sat. Yha, Eue to me take tente, Take hede and Ã¾ou shalte here, What Ã¾at the matere mente, He moved on Ã¾at manere. 5. To ete Ã¾er-of he you defende, I knawe it wele, Ã¾is was his skylle, By-cause he wolde non othir kende Thes grete vertues Ã¾at longes Ã¾er-till. For will Ã¾ou see, Who etes the frute of goode and ille shalle haue knowyng as wele as hee. Eua. Why what-kynne thyng art Ã¾ou, Ã¾at telles Ã¾is tale to me? Sat. A worme Ã¾at wotith wele how Ã¾at yhe may wirshipped be. 6. Eua. What wirshippe shulde we wynne ther-by? To ete Ã¾er-of vs nedith it nought, We have lordshippe to make maistrie Of alle Ã¾ynge Ã¾at in erthe is wrought. Sat. Woman! do way! To gretter state ye may be broughte, and ye will do as I schall saye. Eua. To do is vs full lothe, Ã¾at shuld oure god myspaye. Sat. Nay, certis it is no wathe, Ete it safely ye maye. 7. For perille ryght Ã¾er none in lyes, But worshippe and a grete wynnynge, For right als god yhe shalle be wyse, And pere to hym in all-kyn thynge. Ay! goddis shalle ye be! Of ille and gode to haue knawyng, For to be als wise as he. Eua. Is Ã¾is soth Ã¾at Ã¾ou sais? Sat. Yhe! why trowes Ã¾ou no?t me? I wolde be no-kynnes wayes telle no?t but trouthe to Ã¾e. 8. Eua. Than wille I to thy techyng traste, And fange Ã¾is frute vnto owre foode. (Et tunc debet accipere pomum. Sat. Byte on boldly, be nought a-basshed, And bere Adam to amende his mode, And eke his blisse. (Tunc Satanas recedet. Eua. Adam! have here of frute full goode. Ad. Alas! woman, why toke Ã¾ou Ã¾is? Owre lorde comaunded vs bothe to tente Ã¾e tree of his. Thy werke wille make hym wrothe, Allas! Ã¾ou hast don a mys. 9. Eue. Nay Adam, greve Ã¾e nought at it, And I shal saie Ã¾e reasonne why, A worme has done me for to witte, We shalle be as goddis, Ã¾ou and I, yf Ã¾at we ete Here of this tree; Adam, for-thy lette noght Ã¾at worshippe for to gete. For we shalle be als wise als god Ã¾at is so grete, And als mekill of prise; forthy ete of Ã¾is mete. 10. Adam. To ete it wolde y nought eschewe, Myght I me sure in thy saying. Eue. Byte on boldely, for it es trewe, We shalle be goddis and knawe al thyng. Adam. To wynnne Ã¾at name, I schalle it taste at thy techyng. (Accipit et comedit. Allas! what haue I done, for shame! Ille counsaille woo worthe the! A! Eue, Ã¾ou art to blame, To Ã¾is entysed Ã¾ou me, me shames with my lyghame! 11. For I am naked as me thynke. Eue. Allas! Adam, right so am I. Adam. And for sorowe sere why ne myght we synke, For we haue greved god almyghty Ã¾at made me man. Brokyn his bidyng bittirly, allas! Ã¾at euer we it began. Ãis werke, Eue, hast Ã¾ou wrought, and made Ã¾is bad bargayne. Eue. Nay, Adam, wite me nought. Adam. Do wey, lefe Eue, whame Ã¾an? 12. Eue. The worme to wite wele worthy were, With tales vntrewe he me be-trayed. Adam. Allas! Ã¾at I lete at thy lare, Or trowed Ã¾e trufuls Ã¾at Ã¾ou me saide. So may I byde, For I may banne Ã¾at bittir brayde, And drery dede Ã¾at I it dyde. Oure shappe for doole me defes, where with Ã¾ay shalle be hydde. Eue. Late vs take there fygge leves, sythen it is Ã¾us be-tydde. 13. Adam. Ryght as Ã¾ou sais so shalle it bee, For we are naked and all bare, Full wondyr fayne I wolde hyde me, Fro my lordis sight, and I wiste whare, where I ne roght. [The Lord calls. Dom. Adam! Adam! Adam. Lorde! Dom. Where art thou, yhare? Adam. I here Ã¾e lorde and seys the no?t. Dom. Say, wheron is it longe Ã¾is werke, why hast Ã¾ou wrought? Adam. Lorde, Eue garte me do wronge and to Ã¾at bryg me brought. 14. Dom. Say, Eue, why hast Ã¾ou garte thy make Ete frute I bad Ã¾ei shuld hynge stille, And comaunded none of it to take? Eue. A worme lord, entysed me ther-till, So wel away! That euer I did Ã¾at dede so dill! Dom. A! wikkid worme, woo worthe Ã¾e ay, For Ã¾ou on Ã¾is maner hast made Ã¾am swilke affraye; My malysoune haue Ã¾ou here, with all Ã¾e myght y may. 15. And on thy wombe Ã¾an shall Ã¾ou glyde, And be ay full of enmyte To al man kynde on ilke a side, And erthe it shalle thy sustynaunce be to ete & drynke. Adam and Eue, alsoo, yhe In erthe Ã¾an shalle ye swete and swynke, And trauayle for youre fode. Adam. Allas! whanne myght we synke, We that haues alle worldis goode, ful defly may vs thynke. 16. Dom. Now Cherubyn, myn aungell bryght, To middilerth tyte go dryve these twoo. Ang. Alle redy, lorde, as it is right, Syn thy wille is Ã¾at it be soo, and thy lykyng. [To Adam and Eve. Adam and Eue do you to goo, For here may ?e make no dwellyng, Goo yhe forthe faste to fare, of sorowe may yhe synge. Adam. Allas! for sorowe and care! owre handis may we wryng. Et sic finis.
